and filter design.

entry.title: DTMF_score Essay 4
entry.question:
You are asked to design a simpler dtmfscore function, call it myscore

Design a myscore function that will detect whether any of the four keys in the 4th row of the touch-tone keypad has been pressed. The myscore function should return a 1 if this is the case, or 0 otherwise. The only input to this new myscore function should be the dtmf signal from the one key that was pressed (i.e., assume that dtmfcut has already run). Any filter coefficients needed in myscore should be calculated (i.e., do NOT assume that dtmfdesign has run).

For full credit, outline the SPECIFIC steps by which you would accomplish this. You should also include some of your own sample MATLAB code to illustrate how it would be done.

NOTE: it is possible to do this with one BPF, so you should use the simplest method.

entry.title: Cascading Two Systems -- magnitude of frequency response (1)
entry.question:
bb is the filter coefficient vector for an overall system consisting of two cascaded FIR nulling filters (same kind of filters used in the Nulling Filters lab) that will remove frequencies omega_hat = {a}*pi and {b}*pi.
Suppose that the filter coefficients have been scaled such that bb(1)={c}.

What is the value of the magnitude of the frequency response of this cascaded FIR filter for omega_hat = {N}*pi?

The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits and you can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: Cascading Two Systems -- magnitude of frequency response (2)

Given following two FIR filters coefficients: 
bb1 = [1 {b1} 1];
bb2 = [1 {b2} 1];
What is the value of the magnitude of the frequency response of cascaded FIR filter by bb1 and bb2 for omega_hat = {N}*pi?

The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits and you can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: Convolution Regions 3 (Amp)
entry.question:
A scaled unit-step signal, h(t) = {C}u(t-{m}), is convolved with a pulse signal, x(t) = u(t-{n1}) - u(t-{n2}). The result of the convolution turns out to be:

y(t) = (t - T12)[u(t - T12) - u(t - T23)] + Cu(t - T23)

where the times T12 and T23 can be determined. (C is a constant.)

According to the formula above, the convolution integral produces an output signal that consists of three regions:
Region #1: y(t) = 0 occurs when t is less than or equal to T12.
Region #2: y(t) = t - T12 occurs when T12 < t < T23.
Region #3: y(t) = C occurs when t is greater than or equal to T23. (C is a constant.)

Calculate the value C, which is the amplitude in region #3.
Your answer should be an integer.

entry.title: frequency table -- samples number
Convolution Regions 2
entry.question:
A unit-step signal, h(t) = u(t-{m}), is convolved with a pulse signal, x(t) = u(t+{n1}) - u(t-{n2}).
The result of the convolution turns out to be:

y(t) = (t - T12)[u(t - T12) - u(t - T23)] + Au(t - T23)

where the times T12 and T23 can be determined. (A is a constant.)

According to the formula above, the convolution integral produces an output signal that consists of three regions:
Region #1: y(t) = 0 occurs when t is less than or equal to T12.
Region #2: y(t) = t - T12 occurs when T12 < t < T23.
Region #3: y(t) = A occurs when t is greater than or equal to T23. (A is a constant.)

Calculate the time T12, which is the time at the boundary between region #1 and region #2.
Your answer should be an integer.

entry.title: Fourier Series Synthesis from ak (1)
entry.question:
Suppose that the Fourier series coefficients of a periodic signal are given by the formula: 
kk = -3:3; ak = 1./(1 + kk.*kk);
If the period of the signal is T0 = {T}, and the signal x(t) is synthesized from its Fourier coefficients for |k|<4, determine the numerical value of x({t0}).

entry.title: Phasor Addition - Find Phase

(NOTE: analyze this code, don't run it.)

zz = 0;

end
xx = real(zz);

(Hint: analyze the code, don't run it.)
The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits , and in the range **BETWEEN** -π and π . You can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

Direction finding --- AOA (1)
entry.question:
Given sensor A located to the left of the origin at (-0.5,0) and sensor B located to the right at (0.5,0), i.e., both sensors are on the x-axis.

Suppose:
1. Signal arrival time of A minus the signal arrival time of B is {DT} millisec.
2. Speed of sound is 340 m/s.
3. Distance between the two receiving sensors is 1 m.
4. The source is far away from the sensors.

Compute the angle of arrival from this pair of sensors in radians.
Assume the angle of arrival is **BETWEEN** 0 and π .

The answer should be numeric, with 3 or more significant digits , and in the range **BETWEEN** 0 and π . You can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: alien_essay
entry.question:
This is an ESSAY question about the music vectors you generated in the previous lab.

On a planet in a galaxy far far away, aliens communicate with each other using two different sounds. Somehow they've evolved to using the musical tones for A-440 and C-256 to express themselves. These sounds are actually sinusoids at frequencies 440 Hz and 256 Hz.
To mimic the aliens' speech, you must build a MATLAB program that inputs a vector with a sequence of "A's" and "C's" and then translates into an output vector containing the corresponding sequence of sinusoids. For example, the input might be 
 AC_in = ['C';'C';'A';'C';'A';'A';'A'].
The sampling rate for each sinusoid should be 2400 samples/sec. Also each "A" and "C" lasts for 0.25 seconds.
Please explain IN WORDS the steps that are needed in such a program. Describe the IMPORTANT steps. Also be sure to include some sample MATLAB code.

entry.title: Angle of complex number (2)
entry.question:
Determine the angle of {x} - j{y} in radians.

The answer should be numeric, with 3 or more significant digits and should lie in the range **BETWEEN** -π and π, i.e., (-π,π].
You can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).
WebCT will NOT accept an answer with pi such as pi/8, so you must enter a number.

entry.title: Convolution Regions 1
entry.question:
A unit-step signal, h(t) = u(t-{m}), is convolved with a pulse signal, x(t) = u(t-{n1}) - u(t-{n2}).
The result of the convolution turns out to be:

y(t) = (t - T12)[u(t - T12) - u(t - T23)] + Au(t - T23)

where the times T12 and T23 can be determined. (A is a constant.)

According to the formula above, the convolution integral produces an output signal that consists of three regions:
Region #1: y(t) = 0 occurs when t is less than or equal to T12.
Region #2: y(t) = t - T12 occurs when T12 < t < T23.
Region #3: y(t) = A occurs when t is greater than or equal to T23. (A is a constant.)

Calculate the time T23, which is the time at the boundary between region #2 and region #3.
Your answer should be an integer.

entry.title: Chirp Frequency - find time (2)
entry.question:
(NOTE: analyze this code, don't run it.)
The following MATLAB code generates a linear-FM chirp: 
   tt = 0:(1/80000):200;
   Mu = 830;
   Fo = 0;
   Phi = pi/2;
   xx = cos(2*pi*(Mu*tt.*tt + Fo*tt + Phi));

Determine the exact time (in seconds) at which the instantaneous frequency is equal to 19600 Hz. Recall that Mu controls the chirp rate.

The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits and you can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: Freq Response IIR (II)

entry.question:
In the Power Supply Design Lab, assume that the INPUT signal is represented by the following Fourier Series:

xxt = {a} + {b}*exp(j*{c})*exp(j*240*pi*tt) + {b}*exp(-j*{c})*exp(j*240*pi*tt) + (higher order terms)

and assume that the RC circuit has a Frequency Response given by

H(jw) = 1/({d} + jw)
where w is the frequency in rad/sec.

Determine the DC level of the output. Give your answer as a number to 2 decimal places.

entry.title: Fourier Coefficient 3
Compute Output by Fourier Coefficient -- Amp of 2nd harmonics (1)
entry.question:
An input signal x(t) has the following Fourier Series coefficients 
ak = (2*pi*cos(pi*k))./(pi.^2 - 4*pi.^2*k.^2)
where k is a vector of the coefficients indices. Suppose that 
y(t) = B0 + B1 cos(ω0t + ψ1) + B2 cos(2ω0t + ψ2) + higher harmonic terms
is the output signal when x(t) is passed through the following LTI filter 
H(jω) = j{G}ω/[(ω02-ω2)+j{b}ω]
where B0, B1, B2, and ω0 are positive numbers. Also, ψ1 and ψ2 are between -π and π.

If the Fundamental Frequency of input signal is {f}0 Hz, determine the value of B2.

The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits and you can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

function tone = note(keynum,dur)

tt = 0:1/fs:dur;
f0 = 440*2^((keynum-49)/12);
tone = cos(2*pi*f0*tt);

entry.title: Chirp Frequency Max 4
Fourier Coefficient 1
entry.question:
The Fourier coefficients for a given Fourier Series are defined using the following MATLAB code:
N = 50;
for k = -N:N
  if k == 0
    ak(k+N+1) = 1; %for k = 0
  else
    ak(k+N+1) = (1/(j*pi*k))*(exp(j*k*pi) - 1); %for k ~= 0
  end
end
If the Fundamental Frequency is 10 Hz, what is the Magnitude of ak for the complex exponential term in the Fourier Series whose Frequency is f = -70 Hz ?

The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits and you can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: DTMF_score Essay 1
entry.question:
You are asked to design a simpler dtmfscore function, call it myscore

Design a myscore function that will detect whether any of the four keys in the 1st column of the touch-tone keypad has been pressed. The myscore function should return a 1 if this is the case, or 0 otherwise. The only input to this new myscore function should be the dtmf signal from the one key that was pressed (i.e., assume that dtmfcut has already run). Any filter coefficients needed in myscore should be calculated (i.e., do NOT assume that dtmfdesign has run).

For full credit, outline the SPECIFIC steps by which you would accomplish this. You should also include some of your own sample MATLAB code to illustrate how it would be done.

NOTE: it is possible to do this with one BPF, so you should use the simplest method.

N = 50;

    ak(k+N+1) = 1; %for k = 0

entry.title: Writing & Calling Functions 3

entry.question:
Suppose that 
y(t) = B0 + B1 cos(ω0t + ψ1) + B2 cos(2ω0t + ψ2) + higher harmonic terms
is the output when the input signal 
x(t) = {DC} + cos({w} t)
is passed through a LTI filter 
H(jω) = j{b}ω/[({wc}2-ω2)+j{b}ω]
where B0, B1, B2, and ω0 are positive numbers. Also, ψ1 and ψ2 are between -π and π.

Determine the value of the frequency, ω0.


The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits and you can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: Phasor Addition - Find time-shift -HARD**
entry.question:
tt = -200 : 1/44000 : 200;
zz = 44*exp(3*j) + 34*exp(-3*j);
for k=1:8
  zz = zz.*exp(j*pi/2).*exp(j*62*pi*tt);
end
xx = real(zz);
The result of this MATLAB code is that xx is a sinusoid.
What is the time-shift (in **** MILLISECONDS ****) of xx?
(Hint: analyze the code, don't run it.)
The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits and you can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: Inserting a vector into another one

entry.question:
You are asked to design a simpler dtmfscore function, call it myscore

Design a myscore function that will detect whether any of the four keys in the 3rd column of the touch-tone keypad has been pressed. The myscore function should return a 1 if this is the case, or 0 otherwise. The only input to this new myscore function should be the dtmf signal from the one key that was pressed (i.e., assume that dtmfcut has already run). Any filter coefficients needed in myscore should be calculated (i.e., do NOT assume that dtmfdesign has run).

For full credit, outline the SPECIFIC steps by which you would accomplish this. You should also include some of your own sample MATLAB code to illustrate how it would be done.

NOTE: it is possible to do this with one BPF, so you should use the simplest method.

For the Blackman-sinc bandpass filter design, the formula 10.2π/L can be used to approximate the passband width of the filter (if the width is measured from the lower band edge to the upper band edge at the 0.5 level). It also guarantees that the peak value in the passband will be one.

If the sampling rate is {fs}000 Hz, estimate the filter length that will be needed in the DTMF bandpass filters so that the neighboring passbands will not overlap.

Note: This question does NOT include requirements on the stopbands. If these additional requirements are included, the estimated filter length could be higher.

entry.title: Complex Exponential - Identify Frequency
entry.question:
tt = -100 : 1/{c}000 : 100;
zz = {a}*exp({b}*j)*exp(j*2*pi*{e}0*tt);
for k=1:{d}
   zz = 2*zz.*exp({b}*j).*exp(j*2*pi*{c}0*tt)
end
xx = real(zz);  %<-- create a real sinusoid

The MATLAB code written above produces values of a continuous-time sinusoid for xx.
What is the frequency of xx in Hz?
(Hint: analyze the code, don't run it.)
The answer should be numeric.

entry.title: Direction finding --- AOA (1)
entry.question:
Given sensor A located to the left of the origin at (-0.5,0) and sensor B located to the right at (0.5,0), i.e., both sensors are on the x-axis.

Suppose:
1. Signal arrival time of A minus the signal arrival time of B is {DT} millisec.
2. Speed of sound is 340 m/s.
3. Distance between the two receiving sensors is 1 m.
4. The source is far away from the sensors.

Compute the angle of arrival from this pair of sensors in radians.
Assume the angle of arrival is **BETWEEN** 0 and π .

The answer should be numeric, with 3 or more significant digits , and in the range **BETWEEN** 0 and π . You can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: Direction finding --- AOA (2)
entry.question:
Given sensor A located to the left of the origin at (-1,0) and sensor B located to the right at (1,0), i.e., both sensors are on the x-axis.

Suppose:
1. Signal arrival time of A minus the signal arrival time of B is {DT} millisec.
2. Speed of sound is 340 m/s.
3. Distance between the two receiving sensors is 2 m.
4. The source is far away from the sensors.

Compute the angle of arrival from this pair of sensors in radians.
Assume the angle of arrival is **BETWEEN** 0 and π .

The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits , and in the range **BETWEEN** 0 and π . You can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: Direction finding --- sensors-pair distance (1)
entry.question:
Given sensor A located to the left of the origin and sensor B located to the right, i.e., both sensors are on the x-axis and the origin is in the middle.

Suppose:
1. Signal arrival time of A minus the signal arrival time of B is {DT} millisec.
2. Speed of sound is 340 m/s.
3. Angle of arrival is {AOA} radians.
4. The source is far away from the sensors.

Determine the distance between the two receiving sensors in meters.

The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits . You can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: Direction finding --- sensors-pair distance (2)

entry.title: Direction finding --- TDOA (1)

3. Angle of arrival is {AOA} radians.
4. The source is far away from sensors.

Determine the signal arrival time of A minus the signal arrival time of B in millisecs.


The answer should be numeric, 3 or more significant digits . You can use fixed or exponential notation (e.g. 0.0015 or 1.5e-3).

entry.title: Phasor Addition - Find Amplitude
entry.question:
(NOTE: analyze this code, don't run it.) 
tt = -200 : 1/{a}000 : 200;
zz = {a}*exp(j*pi/2)*exp(j*{b}*pi*tt) + {c}*exp(-j*pi/2)*exp(j*{b}*pi*tt);
for k=1:8
   zz = zz.*exp(j*pi/2).*exp(j*{d}*pi*tt);
end
xx = real(zz);
The result of this MATLAB code is that xx is a vector containing a sinusoid.
What is the amplitude of xx?
(Hint: analyze the code, don't run it.)
The answer should be numeric.

entry.title: Lanczos window - Linear phase
entry.question:
Given the following code: 
M = {MM}0; nn = 0:M;
LW = sin(2*pi/M*(nn-M/2))./(2*pi/M*(nn-M/2)); %-- Lanczos window
LW(M/2 + 1) = 1; %-- fix divide by zero
wc = 0.3*pi;
sincwc = sin(wc*(nn-M/2))./(pi*(nn-M/2)); %-- sinc function
sincwc(M/2 + 1) = wc/pi; %-- fix divide by zero
bb = sincwc.*LW; %-- Filter Coefficients
Determine the phase slope of the frequency response for the filter represented by the coefficients in the vector bb.

entry.title: fsk_essay
entry.question:
This is an ESSAY question about the music vectors you generated in the previous lab.

Digital Communication systems work by sending a sequence of ones and zeros. One method of doing this is called Frequency Shift Keying (FSK) where 1's and 0's correspond to two different sinusoids at different frequencies.
You are to design a MATLAB program that inputs a vector with a sequence of 1's and 0's, and then outputs a vector containing the corresponding sequence of FSK sinusoids. (The input might be something like xin = [1,1,0,1,0,0,1])
For this example you may assume that a "0" corresponds to a frequency of 1650 Hz and a "1" corresponds to a frequency of 1850 Hz. You may assume that a sampling rate of 8000 samples/sec is used. Also each "1" or "0" lasts exactly 0.1 seconds.

M = 50; nn = 0:M;
alpha = 2;
GW =  exp(-0.5*( ((alpha*(nn-M/2))/(M/2)).^2 ));   %-- Gaussian window
wc = 0.3*pi;
sincwc = sin(wc*(nn-M/2))./(pi*(nn-M/2)); %-- sinc function
sincwc(M/2 + 1) = wc/pi; %-- fix divide by zero
bb = sincwc.*GW; %-- Filter Coefficients
Choose all correct answers from the following choices, which will evaluate the frequency response of the filter at frequency "pi".

entry.title: Sampling theorem
entry.question: Set the input frequency to <tt>ƒ<sub>0</sub> = 13.4</tt> Hz. Determine the smallest <font color="darkgreen">integer</font> value of the sampling rate <tt>ƒs</tt> so that no aliasing occurs. The units of <tt>ƒ<sub>s</sub></tt> are samples per second. You must justify your response by citing a theorem or property about sampling.

Set the input frequency to ƒ0 = 13 Hz and the input phase to φ = -1.3 rads. Determine the locations of the spectral lines in the spectrum of the discrete-time signal (middle plot of the bottom row) when the sampling rate is ƒs = 29 Hz. Calculate for the two spectral lines that lie in the range -π ≤ ≤ π. Explain how you calculated the two values for , i.e., give the formula for in terms of ƒ0 and ƒs.

Folded Alias: Set the input frequency to ƒ0 = 13 Hz, the input phase to φ = -1.3 rads, and ƒs = 20 Hz. Write down the formula for the output signal, and then write a justification consisting of three steps:
  1. calculating the values of for the blue spectral lines in the spectrum of the discrete-time signal x[n] shown in the middle plots,
  2. aliasing (blue to red), and
  3. transforming x[n] into y(t) using an equation that describes the ideal D-to-C converter and uses the principal aias.

Set the sampling rate to frequency to ƒs = 23 Hz, and assume that the output signal has a frequency of 9 Hz, and a phase of +1.3. Determine ONE ( ƒ0 , φ ) pair value that will give this output signal. Assume that the amplitude is one.

Set the input frequency to ƒ0 = 13 Hz and the input phase to φ = -1.3 rads. Determine the sampling rate ƒs so that the output signal has a frequency of 9 Hz, and a phase of +1.3 rads. Trial and error helps in getting the answer, but you must write an explanation based on theory.

entry.title: cochlear implant
entry.question: I find is easier to learn the skills and concepts in this course when they are anchored in a physiological system.

Make sure that you understand the colon notation. In particular, explain in words what each of the following MATLAB statements will produce
jkl = 0 : 6 
nnn = 2 : 4 : 17
mmm = 99 : -1 : 88
ttt = 2 : (1/9) : 4
tpi = pi * [ 0:0.1:2 ];

Extracting and/or inserting numbers in a vector is very easy to do. Consider the definition of xx in the first line:
xx = [ zeros(1,3), linspace(0,1,5), ones(1,4) ]
xx(4:7)
size(xx)
length(xx)
xx(2:2:length(xx))
Explain the results echoed from each of the last four lines of the above code.

Observe the result of the following two assignments, where xx was defined in part (b):
yy = xx; yy(4:6) = exp(1)*(1:3)
Now write a statement that will take the vector xx defined in part (b) and replace the even indexed elements (i.e., xx(2), xx(4), etc) with the constant πe. Use a vector replacement, not a loop.

Experiment with vectors in MATLAB. Think of the vector as a list of numbers. Try the following:
xk = cos( pi*(0:11)/4 ); %<-- comment: compute cosines
Explain how the different values of cosine are stored in the vector xk. What is xk(1)? Is xk(0) defined?

NOTES: the semicolon at the end of a statement will suppress the echo to the screen. The text following the % is a comment; it may be omitted.

(A taste of vectorization) Loops can be written in MATLAB, but they are NOT the most efficient way to get things done. It is better to always avoid loops and use the colon notation instead. The following code has a loop that computes values of the cosine function. (The index of yy() must start at 1.) Rewrite this computation without using the loop (follow the style in the previous part).
yy = [ ]; %<-- initialize the yy vector to be empty 
for k=-50:50 
yy(k+51) = exp( -(k/30).*(k/30) ) 
end 
plot(yy)
Explain why it is necessary to write yy(k+51).
What happens if you use <tt>yy(k)</tt> instead?
Also, explain the labels on the x-axis. This functional form is called a Gaussian form.

Plotting is easy in MATLAB for both real and complex numbers. The basic plot command will plot a vector y versus a vector x. Try the following: 
x = [-3 -1 0 1 3 ];
y = x.*x - 3*x;
plot( x, y )
z = x + y*sqrt(-1)
plot( z ) %<-- complex values: plot imag vs. real
Use help arith to learn how the operation xx.*xx works when xx is a vector; compare array multiplication (dot-star) to matrix multiplication.
When unsure about a command, use help.

Use the built-in MATLAB editor to create a script file called mylab1.m containing the following lines:
tt = -1 : 0.01 : 1;
xx = cos( 5*pi*tt );
zz = 1.4*exp(j*pi/2)*exp(j*5*pi*tt);
plot( tt, xx, 'b-', tt, real(zz), 'r.-' ), grid on %<-- plot a sinusoid
title('TEST PLOT of a SINUSOID')
xlabel('TIME (sec)')
Note: Do not save this file or any of your MATLAB files to the local hard disk. Your computer account contains a private networked directory where you can store your own files. Use the MATLAB command addpath() to allow MATLAB to "see" your personal directory (usually the Z: drive).

Use Euler's formula, ejωt=cos(ωt)+jsin(ωt), to explain why the plot of real(zz) is a sinusoid.

Make a calculation of the phase from a time-shift measured on the plot.

What is its phase and amplitude?

Run your script from MATLAB. To run the file mylab1 that you created previously, try 
mylab1      %<-- will run the commands in the file
type mylab1 %<-- will type out the contents of mylab1.m
            %    to the screen

entry.title: Vectorization
entry.question:
Use the vectorization idea to write two or three lines of code that will perform the same task as the following MATLAB script without using a for loop.
%--- make a plot of a weird signal
N = 200;
for k=1:N
   xk(k) = k/60;
   rk(k) = sqrt( xk(k)*xk(k) - 1 );
   sig(k) = exp(j*2*pi*rk(k));
end
plot( xk, real(sig), 'mo-', xk, imag(sig), 'go-' )
Note: there is a difference between the two multiply operations rr*rr and rr.*rr when rr is a vector.

entry.title: M-file to Generate One Sinusoid
entry.question:
Write a function that will generate a single sinusoid, x(t)= Acos(2πƒt+φ). The function should have four input arguments: frequency (ƒ), complex amplitude (X=Aejφ), duration (dur) and starting time (tstart). The function should return two output vectors: the values of the sinusoidal signal (x) and corresponding times (t) at which the sinusoid values are known. Make sure that the function generates exactly 25 values of the sinusoid per period. Call this function onecos(). Hint: use goodcos() from the Pre-Lab part as a starting point. Plot the result from the following call to test your function.
[xx0,tt0] = onecos([2], [5*exp(j*pi/4)], 2, -1); % (freq in Hz)

entry.title: Write the Sum of Sinusoids M-file
entry.question:
Write an M-file called add_sines.m that will synthesize a waveform in the form of (7) using Xk defined in (3). Although for loops are rather inefficient in MATLAB, you must write the function with one outer loop in this lab. The inner loop should be vectorized. The first few statements of the M-file are the comment lines - they should look like:

function [xx,tt] = add_sines(freqs, Camps, dur, tstart)
%ADD_SINES Synthesize a signal from sum of complex exponentials
% usage:
%  [xx,tt] = add_sines(freqs, Camps, dur, tstart)
%    freqs = vector of frequencies (usually none are negative)
%    Camps = vector of COMPLEX amplitudes
%      dur = total time duration of the signal
%   tstart = starting time
%       xx = vector of sinusoidal values
%       tt = vector of times, for the time axis
%
% Note: freqs and Camps must be the same length.
%       Camps(1) corresponds to frequency freqs(1),
%       Camps(2) corresponds to frequency freqs(2), etc.
% The tt vector should be generated with a small time increment that
%       creates 25 samples for the shortest period, i.e., use the period
%       corresponding to the highest frequency in the freqs vector.
The MATLAB syntax length(freqs) returns the number of elements in the vector freqs, so we do not need a separate input argument for the number of frequencies. On the other hand, the programmer (that is you) should provide error checking to make sure that the lengths of freqs and Camps are all the same. See help error.

In order to verify that this M-file can synthesize harmonic sinusoids, try the following test:

[xx0,tt0] = add_sines([12,9,0], [exp(j*pi/4),2i,-4], 1, -0.5); %-Period = ?

Use the notebook feature to make a plot of xx0 within a MS-Word document. Notice that the waveform is periodic. Measure its period and state how the period is related to the fundamental frequency which is 3 Hz in this case.

function yseg = overlap50( yy, T, fs )% OVERLAP50 Fill matrix columns with signal segments
%           overlapped by 50%
%   yy = (long) input signal
%        T, so that 2T = duration of the window
%   fs = sampling rate
% yseg = matrix containing segmented signal
%
L = round(fs*T); L2 = round(fs*T*2);
Ly = length(yy);
n2 = L2;
k=1;
while( n2 < Ly)
  n1 = ????  <==== FILL IN CODE for n1 and n2 
  ychop = yy(n1:n2);
  yseg(:,k) = ychop(:); %--make sure it’s a column
  k = k+1;
  n2 = n2 + L;
end

entry.question: Set the input to a one-sided exponential: <tt>x(t)=e<sup>-0.25t</sup>u(t)</tt>. Strictly speaking you cannot make an infinitely long signal in <tt>cconvdemo</tt>, but if you make the length greater than 25, you will have a very long finite-duration signal which is long enough that you will not see the end within the GUI display.

entry.title: Convolving an Exponential with a Pulse
entry.question:
Use the GUI to produce a plot of the output signal. Use the sliding hand tool to grab the time marker and move it to produce the flip-and-slide effect of convolution.

Note: if you move the hand tool past the end of the plot, the plot will automatically scroll in that direction.

entry.title: Convolving an Exponential with a Pulse
entry.question:
The top panel is a plot of x(τ), overlayed with the “flipped” impulse response h(t-τ) used to produce the “flip and slide” effect of convolution. The middle panel shows the integrand which is the product of x(τ) and h(t-τ). The green-shaded area is where the integral calculates area. As you slide the flipped signal in the top panel, the horizontal length of the green region changes which indicates that the limits of integration are changing. The top two plots are functions of τ, while the bottom plot of y(t) is a function of t. Observe that the output y(t) is composed of three distinct regions: no overlap (on the left side), partial overlap (on the left side), and complete overlap. If you substitute x(t) and h(t) from from parts (a) and (b) into Eq. (1), you can show that the output is given by the piecewise equation 
(5)
Use the GUI to observe that y(t) does indeed have three distinct regions, and use it to confirm that 
T0=0,  T1=0,  T2=3, and T3=3
are the correct values for the boundaries of the regions. Then determine the limits of integration for each integral above. Make sure that you are flipping and sliding h(t).

Also, notice that the limits of integration might depend on the variable t.

entry.title: Frequency Response of an Analog Filter
entry.question: Determine the peak value of the magnitude response and the location of the peak. Use the algebraic form of the frequency response formula <tt>H(jω)</tt> to get the peak value. Also, determine the value when <tt>ω → ∞</tt>, and then determine whether <tt>H(jω)</tt> is a LPF, BPF or HPF. This filter can be produced in the <tt>CLTIdemo</tt>, so use the GUI to plot the frequency response for some value of <tt>a</tt>, say <tt>a=2π(50)</tt>.

entry.title: Frequency Response of an Analog Filter
entry.question:
Now suppose that the parameter a in H(jω) is unknown. One objective of the lab project will be to learn how to test an unknown system to figure out the value of a. The test procedure is as follows: use an input that is the sum of sinusoids, record the output which is also a sum of sinusoids, and then use a spectrum analyzer to extract the amplitudes and phases of the sinusoids. Since the input signal is created as part of the test process, the frequencies of the sinusoids would be known. To simulate this testing process, the MATLAB function Lab11gen has been written to generate test signals and record the outputs. The calling sequence is described below:
function [sigin,sigout] = Lab11gen( gtstring, option )
%LAB11GEN  generate input, filter H(jw), and output
%    sigin = cell array of [Freq (rad/s),Amp,Phase] for each sinusoid in sum
%   sigout = cell array of [Freq (rad/s),Amp,Phase] for each output sinusoid
% gtstring = gt login ID, e.g., ’gburdell8’
%   option = 0, for Warm-up: given input and output, for 1st-order H(jw)=a/(a+jw)
Run the function Lab11gen(’YourGTloginID’,0) to generate data about the input and output sum of sinusoids. Then use the CLTIdemo to set the input signal, and vary the frequency response parameter a to get the correct output. This “trial and error” method shows how a can be found.

Note: It is also possible to write one or two equations to solve for a.

entry.title: Cell Arrays
entry.question: The outputs from the MATLAB function <tt>Lab11gen</tt> are cell arrays. The notation for accessing members of a cell array is to use braces, i.e., <tt>AA{2}</tt> is the second element of the cell array called <tt>AA</tt>. In the case of <tt>Lab11gen</tt>, the members of the cell arrays are row vectors. Each row vector has three elements: the frequency (in rad/s), amplitude and phase of one sinusoidal component in the input signal or output signal. The syntax for getting one member of these row vectors is <tt>AA{n}(k)</tt> which gets the <tt>k</tt>-th element of the <tt>n</tt>-th row vector. For example, to get the frequency of the second sinusoid in the output signal, you would use <tt>sigout{2}(1)</tt>, while <tt>sigin{3}(2)</tt> is the amplitude of the third sinusoid in the input.

State the property of the polynomial coefficients of <tt>A(z) = 1 - a<sub>1</sub>z<sup>-1</sup> - a<sub>2</sub>z<sup>-2</sup></tt> that will guarantee that the two roots of <tt>A(z)</tt> are either both real, or are complex conjugates of each other.

Clear all the poles and zeros from PeZ, using the -A button. Now place a pole pair that makes the following denominator polynomial for H(z): 1 + 0.9z-1 + 0.81z-2, and two zeros to make the numerator 1-z-2. Determine the radius and angles of the poles by factoring. The frequency response has a peak–record the frequency (location) of this peak.

Change the angle of the pole and observe H(ej): move the pole-pair angles to (± 90°), then to (± 60°) and (± 45°). Describe the changes in |H(ejω)|. Concentrate on the height and location of the peak versus frequency .

Start again with the poles and zeros from part (b). Decrease the radial distance of the poles (from the origin) by dragging, and observe how |H(ej)| changes. Even though dragging is imprecise because it’s hard to stay on a constant angle, it is a very informative way to discover the changes in |H(ej)| as you reduce the pole radius.

Increase the radius of the poles by pushing them closer to the unit circle, and then move the poles outside the unit circle. When the pole-pair is outside the unit circle, describe what happens to <tt>h[n]</tt>.

To test your understanding of sampling as well as digital filtering, design a BPF whose passband is centered at 7300 Hz when the sampling rate is 22050 Hz using a two-pole IIR filter as in part (b), i.e., determine a value of r, and the angles of the poles. As a reminder, you are designing a digital filter to be used as the system H(z) in Fig. 2.


Figure 2: Filtering the analog signal x(t) with a digital filter.

Clear all the poles and zeros from PeZ. Then start again with the poles only from part (b), and place two zeros exactly on the unit circle at the same angles as the poles. You will have to calculate the zeros, and then use the Zero Location edit window to enter the exact values. Judging from the frequency response what type of filter have you just implemented? Is the system IIR or FIR?
Write out the expression for H(z) created in part (g). Even though the GUI provides H(z), you should create H(z) by multiplying out first-order terms with the poles and zeros, see eq. (1).

Once again start again with the poles only from part (b). Now place zeros at the conjugate-inverse locations 1/pi*, where pi are the poles. If you have the polar representation of the poles, it would be easy to get the polar representation of these complex-valued zeros. Judging from the frequency response what type of filter have you just implemented? Is the system IIR or FIR?
Write out the expression for H(z) created in part (i). Even though the GUI provides H(z), you should do this from the given poles and zeros. Hint: use MATLAB’s poly function, or eq. (1).
